Don't overdo it on asserting that functions weren't called. Verifying too many mock functions just makes tests brittle. Only include "not called" if it's very important and you can't check it any other way.

nodes.bodyText: nit: remove multiple blank lines
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
+<Configuration status="WARN" monitorInterval="30">
+	<Properties>
+		<Property name="LOG_PATTERN">%d{yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSZ} %p %m%n
+		</Property>
+		<Property name="APP_LOG_ROOT">logs</Property>
+	</Properties>
+	<Appenders>
+		<Console name="Console" target="SYSTEM_OUT" follow="true">
+			<PatternLayout pattern="${LOG_PATTERN}" />
+		</Console>
+
+		<RollingFile name="appLog"
+			fileName="consent-management-server.log"
+			filePattern="consent-management-server-%d{yyyy-MM-dd}-%i.log">
+			<PatternLayout pattern="${LOG_PATTERN}" />
+			<Policies>
+				<SizeBasedTriggeringPolicy size="1MB" />
+			</Policies>
+			<DefaultRolloverStrategy max="1" />
+		</RollingFile>
+	</Appenders>
+	<Loggers>
+
+		<Logger name="com.fda-mystudies-consent-management-server" level="info"
+			additivity="false">
+			<AppenderRef ref="appLog" />
+		</Logger>
+

Don't catch exception

I think these tests would be cleaner and easier to read with the MockMvcController. I was just looking for articles about this and this one https://reflectoring.io/spring-boot-web-controller-test/ provides a lot of helpful information for writing tests that are easy to read and verify.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,84 +2,43 @@
 
 import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

nodes.bodyText: MockMvcController is used to write test cases for @controller classes (Spring MVC Controller), but we are using @RestController to develop RESTful APIs. WireMock is easy to mock the RESTful APIs, so we have used this.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,84 +2,43 @@
 
 import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

nodes.bodyText:
The first example in that blog post uses a @RestController. I tested it out myself and it works just fine here. MockMvc replaces your calls to getRestTemplate().exchange(...) which are not easy to read.
We're not mocking the REST API here, we're testing it. You're using WireMock to stub out external APIs which is not related to what I'm suggesting.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2,84 +2,43 @@
 
 import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

nodes.bodyText: We have updated UserConsentManagementControllerTest to use MockMvc in place of RestTemplate latest commit.
nodes.diffHunk:

 import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

nodes.bodyText: Looks much better. These tests are easy to read now and should also be easy to maintain and update.

 import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

You never pass null into this function. Since it's a test helper remove this check from these methods.
I added it so that in case somebody else uses it in future, they don't need to construct it before calling.

If you haven't written the tests that way I doubt that anyone is going to do it differently in the future. The team is probably just going to copy the style that you used in these tests, that's why I'm spending more time making sure we get the style here right. Also, this won't actually work, because it modifies what headers points to, it doesn't set it for the caller.
This has been updated as requested.
Use ObjectMapper to serialize the Request Bean instead of manually constructing the requests.

consent = new ObjectMapper().readTree(jsonString);

Prefer @Data to combine a bunch of these properties, or @Value if we don't need setters.

This is coming from MyStudiesUserRegUtil.ErrorCodes.SUCCESS. Use that value directly in your test.
